fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A context is a finite list of distinct variables. Recall that each variable has a specified sort. A context is said to be suitable for a formula (resp., term) if every free variable of that formula (resp., term) appears in the given context.
A (first-order) signature \Sigma consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: A collection of function symbols, each comes with a prescribed type denoted as follows: f \colon A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} \to B where A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n},B are sorts. Unary (n = 0) function symbols are also called constant symbols.

A collection of relation symbols, each comes with a prescribed type denoted as follows: R \rightarrowtail A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} where A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} are sorts. Unary (n = 0) relation symbols are usually called atomic propositions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Each sort comes with a collection of variables. We assume that given any collection of variables of sort A, there is a variable of sort A not in the given collection.
Let \Sigma be a signature. The collection of (raw) terms over \Sigma is inductively generated by the following rules:

fr:ul.fr:li: Each variable x of sort A is a term of sort A.

Let us write t \colon A if t is a term of sort A. If f \colon A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} \to B is a function symbol and t_{1} \colon A_{1} , \ldots , t_{n} \colon A_{n} are terms of corresponding sorts, then f(t_{1}, \ldots ,t_{n}) \colon B.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The collection of infinitary first-order formulas over a signature \Sigma is defined inductively by the following rules:

fr:ol.fr:li: For each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} and terms t_{1} \colon A_{1} , \ldots , t_{n} \colon A_{n}, R(t_{1}, \ldots ,t_{n}) is a formula.
For any two terms of the same sort s,t \colon A, s = t is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \wedge \psi is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \vee \psi is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \Rightarrow \psi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula, then \lnot \varphi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula and x \colon A is a variable, then \exists x \colon A . \mkern5mu \varphi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula and x \colon A is a variable, then \forall x \colon A . \mkern5mu \varphi is a formula.
If I is a set and for each i \in I, \varphi _{i} is a formula, then \bigvee _{i \in I} \varphi _{i} is a formula.
If I is a set and for each i \in I, \varphi _{i} is a formula, then \bigwedge _{i \in I} \varphi _{i} is a formula.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Fragments of this collection are defined as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li: The collection of atomic formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 and 2.
The collection of Horn formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 4.
The collection of regular formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 4 and 9.
The collection of coherent formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 6 and 9.
The collection of first-order formulas over \Sigma is inductive generated by 1 through 10.
The collection of geometric formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 6, 9, and 11.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A context is a finite list of distinct variables. Recall that each variable has a specified sort. A context is said to be suitable for a formula (resp., term) if every free variable of that formula (resp., term) appears in the given context.
A sequent over a signature \Sigma is a formal expression of the form \Gamma | \varphi \vdash \psi, where \varphi and \psi are formulas and \Gamma is a context suitable for both \varphi and \psi.

An axiomatization of a theory \mathscr { T } over a signature \Sigma is a collection of sequents over \Sigma. These sequents are the (non-logical) axioms of (the given axiomatization of) \mathscr { T }.
A sequent over a signature \Sigma is a formal expression of the form \Gamma | \varphi \vdash \psi, where \varphi and \psi are formulas and \Gamma is a context suitable for both \varphi and \psi.
